name: Matomo
desc: A real-time web analytics application

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: The matomo package to use.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: Enable Matomo web analytics with php-fpm backend. Either the nginxoption or the webServerUser option is mandatory.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: URL of the host, without https prefix. You may want to change it ifyou run Matomo on a different URL than matomo.yourdomain.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: Enable periodic archive processing, which generates aggregatedreports from the visits.This means that you can safely disable browser triggers for Matomoarchiving, and safely enable to delete old visitor logs. Before deletingvisitor logs, make sure though that you runsystemctl start matomo-archive-processing.service at leastonce without errors if you have already collected data before.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: With this option, you can customize an nginx virtualHost whichalready has sensible defaults for Matomo. Either this option or thewebServerUser option is mandatory. Set this to {} to just enable thevirtualHost if you don’t need any customization. If enabled, then bydefault, the serverName is${user}.${config.networking.hostName}.${config.networking.domain},SSL is active, and certificates are acquired via ACME. If this is set tonull (the default), no nginx virtualHost will be configured.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: Name of the web server user that forwards requests to services.phpfpm.pools.<name>.socket thefastcgi socket for Matomo if the nginx option is not used. Either thisoption or the nginx option is mandatory. If you want to use anotherwebserver than nginx, you need to set this to that server’s user andpass fastcgi requests to index.php, matomo.phpand piwik.php (legacy name) to this socket.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: A host of an existing Let’s Encrypt certificate to use. This isuseful if you have many subdomains and want to avoid hitting the rate limit.Alternately, you can generate a certificate through enableACME. Note thatthis option does not create any certificates, nor it does add subdomainsto existing ones – you will need to create them manually using security.acme.certs.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: Path to root SSL certificate for stapling and clientcertificates.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: Path to server SSL certificate key.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: Path to server SSL certificate.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: Name of this virtual host. Defaults to attribute name invirtualHosts.

options.desc: Additional names of virtual hosts served by this virtual hostconfiguration.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: The path of the web root directory.

options.desc: Create an individual listening socket . It is required to specifyonly once on one of the hosts.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: Whether to listen for and reject all HTTPS connections to this vhost.Useful in defaultserver blocks to avoid serving the certificate for another vhost. Usesthe ssl_reject_handshake directive available in nginxversions 1.19.4 and above.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: HTTP status used by globalRedirect andforceSSL. Possible usecases include temporary (302, 307)redirects, keeping the request method and body (307, 308), or explicitlyresetting the method to GET (303). See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Redirections.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix

options.desc: Listen addresses and ports for this virtual host. IPv6 addresses mustbe enclosed in square brackets. Note: this option overridesaddSSL and onlySSL.If you only want to set the addresses manually and not the ports,take a look at listenAddresses.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: Whether to enable kTLS support. Implementing TLS in the kernel (kTLS)improves performance by significantly reducing the need for copyingoperations between user space and the kernel. Required Nginx version1.21.4 or later.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: Whether to enable the HTTP/0.9 protocol negotiation used in QUICinteroperability tests. This requires using pkgs.nginxQuicpackage which can be achieved by settingservices.nginx.package = pkgs.nginxQuic; and activate theQUIC transport protocolservices.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.quic = true;. Notethat special application protocol support is experimental andnot yet recommended for production. Read more at https://quic.nginx.org/

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: Whether to enable the HTTP/3 protocol. This requires usingpkgs.nginxQuic package which can be achieved by settingservices.nginx.package = pkgs.nginxQuic; and activate theQUIC transport protocolservices.nginx.virtualHosts.<name>.quic = true;. Notethat HTTP/3 support is experimental and not yet recommended forproduction. Read more at https://quic.nginx.org/ HTTP/3availability must be manually advertised, preferably in each locationblock.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: Whether to enable the HTTP/2 protocol. Note that (as of writing) dueto nginx’s implementation, to disable HTTP/2 you have to disable it onall vhosts that use a given IP address / port. If there is one serverblock configured to enable http2, then it is enabled for all serverblocks on this IP. See https://stackoverflow.com/a/39466948/263061.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: If set, all requests for this host are redirected (defaults to 301,configurable with redirectCode) to the given hostname.

options.name: web-apps/matomo.nix
options.desc: Whether to add a separate nginx server block that redirects (defaultsto 301, configurable with redirectCode) all plain HTTPtraffic to HTTPS. This will set defaults for listen tolisten on all interfaces on the respective default ports (80, 443),where the non-SSL listens are used for the redirect vhosts.

name: BorgBackup
desc: Deduplicating archiver with compression and encryption

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: The borgbackup package to use.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Deduplicating backups using BorgBackup. Adding a job will cause aborg-job-NAME wrapper to be added to your system path, so that you canperform maintenance easily. See also the chapter about BorgBackup in theNixOS manual.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Serve BorgBackup repositories to given public SSH keys, restrictingtheir access to the repository only. See also the chapter aboutBorgBackup in the NixOS manual. Also, clients do not need to specify theabsolute path when accessing the repository, i.e.user@machine:. is enough. (Note colon and dot.)

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: When or how often the backup should run. Must be in the formatdescribed in systemd.time(7). Ifyou do not want the backup to start automatically, use [ ].It will generate a systemd service borgbackup-job-NAME. You may triggerit manually via systemctl restart borgbackup-job-NAME.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: The user borg serve is run as. User or group needs writepermission for the specified path.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Storage quota for the repository. This quota is ensured for allsub-repositories if allowSubRepos is enabled but not for the overallstorage space used.
options.type: null or string matching the pattern [[:digit:].]+[KMGTP]?

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Where to store the backups. Note that the directory is createdautomatically, with correct permissions.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: The group borg serve is run as. User or group needs writepermission for the specified path.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Public SSH keys that can only be used to append new data (archives)to the repository. Note that archives can still be marked as deleted andare subsequently removed from disk upon accessing the repo with fullwrite access, e.g. when pruning.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Public SSH keys that are given full write access to this repository.You should use a different SSH key for each repository you write to,because the specified keys are restricted to running borg serve and can onlyaccess this single repository.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Allow clients to create repositories in subdirectories of thespecified path.These can be accessed using user@machine:path/to/subrepo.Note that a quotaapplies to repositories independently. Therefore, if this is enabled,clients can create multiple repositories and upload an arbitrary amountof data.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: The user borg isrun as. User or group need read permission for the specified paths.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Remote or local repository to back up to.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Whether the repo (which must be local) is a removable device.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: By default, borg cannot write anywhere on the system but$HOME/.config/borg and $HOME/.cache/borg. If,for example, your preHook script needs to dump files somewhere, putthose directories here.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Only consider archive names starting with this prefix for pruning. Bydefault, only archives created by this job are considered. Use"" or null to consider all archives.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Prune a repository by deleting all archives not matching any of thespecified retention options. See borg help prune for the available options.
options.type: attribute set of (signed integer or string matching the pattern [[:digit:]]+[Hdwmy])

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Set the PrivateTmp option for the systemd-service. Setto false if you need sockets or other files from global /tmp.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Shell commands to run before the backup. This can for example be usedto mount file systems.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Shell commands to run after borg prune.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Shell commands to run after borg init.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Shell commands to run just before exit. They are executed even if aprevious command exits with a non-zero exit code. The latter isavailable as $exitStatus.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Shell commands to run after borg create. The name of the created archive isstored in $archiveName.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Include/exclude paths matching the given patterns. The first matchingpatterns is used, so if an include pattern (prefix +)matches before an exclude pattern (prefix -), the file isbacked up. See borg help patternsfor pattern syntax.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Path(s) to back up. Mutually exclusive with dumpCommand.
options.type: null or ((list of string) or string convertible to it)

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Prevents the system from sleeping while backing up.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: The group borg is run as. User or group needs read permission for thespecified paths.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Fail the whole backup job if any borg command returns a warning (exitcode 1), for example because a file changed during backup.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Additional arguments for borg prune. Can also be set at runtime using$extraPruneArgs.
options.type: string or (list of string) convertible to it

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Additional arguments for borg init. Can also be set at runtime using$extraInitArgs.
options.type: string or (list of string) convertible to it

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix

options.type: string or (list of string) convertible to it

options.type: string or (list of string) convertible to it

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Additional arguments for all borg calls the service has. Handle with care.
options.type: string or (list of string) convertible to it

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Exclude paths matching any of the given patterns. See borg help patterns forpattern syntax.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Environment variables passed to the backup script. You can forexample specify which SSH key to use.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: The passphrase the backups are encrypted with. Mutually exclusivewith passCommand. Ifyou do not want the passphrase to be stored in the world-readable Nixstore, use passCommand.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: A command which prints the passphrase to stdout. Mutually exclusivewith passphrase.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Encryption mode to use. Setting a mode other than "none"requires you to specify a passCommand or a passphrase.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Backup the stdout of this program instead of filesystem paths.Mutually exclusive with paths.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Run borg init ifthe specified repodoes not exist. You should set this to false if therepository is located on an external drive that might not always bemounted.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Arguments passed to date to create a timestamp suffix for the archivename.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Compression method to use. Refer to borg help compression for all availableoptions.

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: How to name the created archives. A timestamp, whose format isdetermined by dateFormat, will be appended. The full name can bemodified at runtime ($archiveName). Placeholders like{hostname} must not be used. Use null for nobase name.
options.type: null or string matching the pattern [^/{}]+

options.name: backup/borgbackup.nix
options.desc: Append a .failed suffix to the archive name, which isonly removed if borg create has a zero exit status.

options.name: network-filesystems/glusterfs.nix

Ifhowever you want running volume processes (glusterfsd) and thus glustermounts not be interrupted when glusterd is restarted (for example, whenyou want to restart them manually at a later time), set this to‘process’.

options.name: networking/strongswan.nix

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Optional numeric identifier by which authentication rounds aresorted. If not specified rounds are ordered by their position in theconfig file/vici message.StrongSwan default: 0

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Optional numeric identifier by which authentication rounds aresorted. If not specified rounds are ordered by their position in theconfig file/vici message.StrongSwan default: 0

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: List of certificates to accept for authentication. The certificatesmay use a relative path from the swanctl x509 directory oran absolute path.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: IKE identity to expect for authentication round. When usingcertificate authentication, the IKE identity must be contained in thecertificate, either as subject or as subjectAltName.StrongSwan default: "%any"

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: List of CA certificates to accept for authentication. Thecertificates may use a relative path from the swanctlx509ca directory or an absolute path.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: List of remote selectors to include in CHILD_SA. See local_ts for a descriptionof the selector syntax.StrongSwan default: ["dynamic"]

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Enable IPComp compression before encryption. If enabled, IKE tries tonegotiate IPComp compression to compress ESP payload data prior toencryption.StrongSwan default: false

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Whether this connection is a mediation connection, that is, whetherthis connection is used to mediate other connections using the IKEv2Mediation Extension. Mediation connections create no CHILD_SA.StrongSwan default: false

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Whether to install IPsec policies or not. Disabling this can beuseful in some scenarios e.g. MIPv6, where policies are not managed bythe IKE daemon. Since 5.3.3.StrongSwan default: true

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: List of raw public keys to accept for authentication. The public keysmay use a relative path from the swanctl pubkey directoryor an absolute path.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Whether to install outbound FWD IPsec policies or not. Enabling thisis required in case there is a drop policy that would match and blockforwarded traffic for this CHILD_SA. Since 5.5.1.StrongSwan default: false

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Time to schedule IKE reauthentication. IKE reauthentication recreatesthe IKE/ISAKMP SA from scratch and re-evaluates the credentials. Inasymmetric configurations (with EAP or configuration payloads) it mightnot be possible to actively reauthenticate as responder. The IKEv2reauthentication lifetime negotiation can instruct the client to performreauthentication.Reauthentication is disabled by default. Enabling it usually may leadto small connection interruptions, as strongSwan uses abreak-before-make policy with IKEv2 to avoid any conflicts withassociated tunnel resources.StrongSwan default: "0s"

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Whether to copy the ECN (Explicit Congestion Notification) headerfield to/from the outer IP header in tunnel mode. Controlling thisbehavior is not supported by all kernel interfaces.StrongSwan default: true

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Differentiated Services Field Codepoint to set on outgoing IKEpackets for this connection. The value is a six digit binary encodedstring specifying the Codepoint to set, as defined in RFC 2474.StrongSwan default: "000000"

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Whether to copy the DF bit to the outer IPv4 header in tunnel mode.This effectively disables Path MTU discovery (PMTUD). Controlling thisbehavior is not supported by all kernel interfaces.StrongSwan default: true

options.name: networking/networkmanager.nix
options.desc: Enable the StrongSwan plugin.If you enable this option the networkmanager_strongswanplugin will be added to the networking.networkmanager.plugins option so youdon’t need to do that yourself.

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: List of named IP pools to allocate virtual IP addresses and otherconfiguration attributes from. Each name references a pool by name fromeither the pools section or an external pool.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Optional fixed priority for IPsec policies. This could be useful toinstall high-priority drop policies. The default of 0 uses dynamicallycalculated priorities based on the size of the traffic selectors.StrongSwan default: 0

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Remote UDP port for IKE communication. If the default of port500 is used, automatic IKE port floating to port4500 is used to work around NAT issues.StrongSwan default: 500

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Fixed reqid to use for this CHILD_SA. This might be helpful in somescenarios, but works only if each CHILD_SA configuration is instantiatednot more than once. The default of 0 uses dynamic reqids, allocatedincrementally.StrongSwan default: 0

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Contents of the strongswan.conf file.

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Authorization group memberships to require. The peer must provemembership to at least one of the specified groups. Group membership canbe certified by different means, for example by appropriate AttributeCertificates or by an AAA backend involved in the authentication.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: IPsec replay window to configure for this CHILD_SA. Larger valuesthan the default of 32 are supported using the Netlinkbackend only, a value of 0 disables IPsec replayprotection.StrongSwan default: 32

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Timeout before closing CHILD_SA after inactivity. If no traffic hasbeen processed in either direction for the configured timeout, theCHILD_SA gets closed due to inactivity. The default value of 0 disablesinactivity checks.StrongSwan default: "0s"

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Charon by default uses the normal retransmission mechanism andtimeouts to check the liveness of a peer, as all messages are used forliveness checking. For compatibility reasons, with IKEv1 a custominterval may be specified; this option has no effect on connectionsusing IKEv2.StrongSwan default: "0s"

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Interval to check the liveness of a peer actively using IKEv2INFORMATIONAL exchanges or IKEv1 R_U_THERE messages. Active DPD checkingis only enforced if no IKE or ESP/AH packet has been received for theconfigured DPD delay.StrongSwan default: "0s"

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: List of virtual IPs to request in IKEv2 configuration payloads orIKEv1 Mode Config. The wildcard addresses 0.0.0.0 and:: request an arbitrary address, specific addresses may bedefined. The responder may return a different address, though, or noneat all.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Enables Aggressive Mode instead of Main Mode with IdentityProtection. Aggressive Mode is considered less secure, because the IDand HASH payloads are exchanged unprotected. This allows a passiveattacker to snoop peer identities, and even worse, start dictionaryattacks on the Preshared Key.StrongSwan default: false

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: IKE major version to use for connection.1 uses IKEv1 aka ISAKMP,2 uses IKEv2.A connection using the default of 0 accepts both IKEv1 and IKEv2 asresponder, and initiates the connection actively with IKEv2.StrongSwan default: 0

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: List of certificate candidates to use for authentication. Thecertificates may use a relative path from the swanctl x509directory or an absolute path.The certificate used for authentication is selected based on thereceived certificate request payloads. If no appropriate CA can belocated, the first certificate is used.StrongSwan default: []

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: HMAC-SHA-256 is used with 128-bit truncation with IPsec. Forcompatibility with implementations that incorrectly use 96-bittruncation this option may be enabled to configure the shortertruncation length in the kernel. This is not negotiated, so this onlyworks with peers that use the incorrect truncation length (or have thisoption enabled).StrongSwan default: false

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: Action to perform for this CHILD_SA on DPD timeout. The default clearcloses the CHILD_SA and does not take further action. trap installs atrap policy, which will catch matching traffic and tries to re-negotiatethe tunnel on-demand. restart immediately tries to re-negotiate theCHILD_SA under a fresh IKE_SA.StrongSwan default: "clear"

options.name: networking/strongswan-swanctl/module.nix
options.desc: List of raw public key candidates to use for authentication. Thepublic keys may use a relative path from the swanctl pubkeydirectory or an absolute path.Even though multiple local public keys could be defined in principle,only the first public key in the list is used for authentication.StrongSwan default: []
